# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is the Julia code that fulfills this task:

```julia
using DataFrames, Tables

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    filter!(r -> (r.manufacturer == "audi" && 
                   r.model == "a4" || r.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    new_column = fill(true, size(df)[1])
    push!(df, :audi_a4_type => new_column)
    return df
end
```
This function works by first filtering out all rows that do not meet the criteria (manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro"). Then it creates a new column of `true` values, which are pushed onto the DataFrame. Finally, it returns the modified DataFrame.

If you run this function on your provided dataset (`df_cars`), the output should be:
```julia

│ 1   │ audi           │ a4         │

│ 8   │ audi           │ a4         │
│ 9   │ audi           │ a4 quattro │
│ 10  │ audi           │ a4 quattro │
│     │                │ true       │
```
